e8p5yxm.Author: tommygunz007
e8p5yxm.Text:
So, educate me, because I am a Debbie Downer.

Hypothetically, let's say using Bitcoin for Purchases is only 1% as opposed to the 3% merchants pay, and that the merchant processing company converts it automatically back to FIAT and deposits it into their bank for that 1%. 

And, hypothetically you the customer would have to pay a small fee to convert your FIAT in America to Bitcoin to buy something in Bitcoin, involving (1) an extra step, and (2) an incurred cost of conversion. 

So, vendors would offer a 1% discount if you pay with Bitcoin, so that you the customer, save a very small amount, and the vendor saves a large amount over the cost of a month. 

The question then is, will someone convert to bitcoin to merely save a few cents and also do the extra step? And what's there to prevent Visa or MasterCard from dropping their prices to small amounts too? After all, if they use blockchain technology, then every transaction becomes guaranteed and secure, and their costs drop as there is less fraud so they can lower the costs to the merchants.

Is this accurate?

e8nspgg.Author: TheGreatMuffin
e8nspgg.Text:
This is a good tool to see what a hash function does: https://www.movable-type.co.uk/scripts/sha256.html  

any input has a unique "fingerprint". If you change the slightest bit ("apples" instead of "apple", f.ex), the whole fingerprint changes. You can type in some similar words/text strings in the linked site.  

SHA256 or similar algorithms simply produce "fingerprints" of whatever data you put into it.

e8nu4g4.Author: roveridcoffee
e8nu4g4.Text: Thanks for the reply. I just wonder if this "fingerprint" is a valid private key for btc (or other sha256 crypto currencies for that matter) or not.

e8ntt4i.Author: roveridcoffee
e8ntt4i.Text: Yes, that is understood. Just wondering if encrypting really anything leads to something usable on, for the bitcoin network. For instance encrypting "abc" with sha256 gives result "BA7816BF8F01CFEA414140DE5DAE2223B00361A396177A9CB410FF61F20015AD". (source: https://passwordsgenerator.net/sha256-hash-generator/) Is that a valid private key?

e8okzt0.Author: ely_obo
e8okzt0.Text:
SHA 256 is a hash function, which is not encryption.  


In answer to the original question, no.  The hash is not a private key, nor are addresses are sha256 hashes (they're apparently ripemd160 hashes of the sha256 hash of the \*public\* key).

e8ocubv.Author: The-Physicist
e8ocubv.Text: I didn’t even read your whole post because it’s so ridiculous. Hindsight is 20/20.  If you were investing for the long term (years) like me then this bear market means nothing, because it’s temporary.  Back earlier this year when people were yelling HODL, we were trying to prevent an irrational bear market from taking hold. We lost. However, the market could very well have turned around faster than anyone expected, so hodling could have been a good idea even in the short term.  Again if you are not a daytrader, but instead are a long term investor than HODLING has been proven to be the right strategy during bitcoin’s 9 year track record. And I believe this will continue to be true in the years to come.

e8opqii.Author: whalecheetah
e8opqii.Text:
Google Bitcoin chart.

Now throw a dart anywhere on the board except late 2017 and in a few years you will almost certainly be able to include that.

Ever since 2009 there has been the risk of this whole project collapsing and that risk has not went away. If this was a certain investment it would not have the ability to generate returns. That element of risk and not knowing if it's going to continue is what separates people. A lot of people look at this and they see the price decline this year and they think that is going to continue forever and the whole thing is over. Many of those people have already sold. It's even more common with this new breed of Internet skeptic. Very few people have been able to hang on through the Long Haul. Bitcoin is very good at breaking almost everyone with fear panic and emotion even though like I said earlier. All you have to do is throw a dart on a chart and the price will be lower than it is today. You have around a 97% chance of that Dart hitting a lower number than where we are right now
